Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Paleobiogeography, paleoecology, and continued investigation of a diverse, terminal Miocene, primate-bearing fauna from southern China

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The early and middle Miocene (ca. 23 to 11 million years ago) witnessed an expansion of the world's tropical and subtropical forests, and an increase in the diversity and distribution of mammals that thrived in forests with low seasonality and high productivity. Apes flourished under these conditions in the Old World. The contraction of subtropical forests in the late Miocene in Eurasia resulted in a decline in the diversity and abundance of apes, and the rise of monkeys and other mammals able to survive in more open and seasonal habitats. Several fossil sites in southern China provide evidence of this critical transition. In this project, the fossil site of Shuitangba, Yunnan Province, China, will be investigated because it has yielded the abundant and well-preserved remains of many mammal species of terminal Miocene age (~6.1 mya). Among them are an ape and a monkey, the first such co-occurrence in the Miocene of Eurasia. Recovery and detailed study of the fossils by an international team of American and Chinese investigators will make possible the characterization of the paleoenvironment of Shuitangba and the nature and adaptations of the site's many species, especially its primates and carnivores. Direct comparison of the Shuitangba biota with others of similar age in eastern Asia will provide a clearer idea of the nature and pace of environmental evolution in the region.

Shuitangba captures a unique snapshot of the transition from the widespread evergreen forests of the Miocene to the more heterogeneous and seasonal habitats that followed. This project thus promotes the understanding of an ecosystem poised at the tipping point of a major change. The Shuitangba fauna and environment provide an unusually clear picture of a distinctive regional ecosystem that contained long-established species alongside new arrivals. A better understanding of the adaptations of species within such ecosystems may shed light on the dynamics of modern unstable environments.

This project fosters strong international collaboration with Chinese scholars, including advanced training for Chinese paleoanthropologists, paleobiologists, and fossil preparators, and promotes public science education in China through media coverage and development of museum displays. A junior US scientist will be integrally involved in the research, and US undergraduate students also will receive substantial participatory research training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The period spanning the late Miocene through the early Pliocene (8-4 million year ago) witnessed great changes in terrestrial environments, due to changes in continental and oceanic configurations, mountain building, and global and local patterns of atmospheric circulation. Landscape heterogeneity and seasonality increased during this time and across Eurasia, there was a decrease in the areal extent of evergreen tropical and subtropical forests that resulted in the loss of species dependent on the resources in these environments. The paucity of sites from this period means that we have a poor understanding of local ecosystem changes in the face of large-scale, global and regional environmental and climatic changes. Shuitangba, an ape-bearing site dated to 6.1 million years ago, in Yunnan Province, China, is one of the few sites that can help shed light on this important time period. Our goal is to better understand late Miocene ecosystems in East Asia by examining the faunal community of Shuitangba and the habitat in which they live. To do so, we had three objectives: (1) recover additional fossil remains from Shuitangba, (2) conduct taphonomic and paleoecological analyses on the fossil assemblage, and (3) analyze vertebrate remains to address questions concerning taxonomy, phylogeny, and functional morphology. We were able to accomplish activities related to these objectives, the results of which have important outcomes as they relate to our intellectual merit and broader impacts goals.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes

 We have deepened our field’s understanding of a terrestrial ecosystem during a critical transitional time period through peer-reviewed publications and presentations that detail the community composition (taxonomy and systematics) and community structure (ecological niche) of the Shuitangba mammalian fauna. Three species previously unknown to science have been described and we have gained insight into the ecological niches that they, and the other taxa at Shuitangba, occupied. We also have a deeper understanding of the paleoenvironment at Shuitangba and how its wet and wooded habitat may have allowed Shuitangba to function as a refugium.

Broader Impact Outcomes

This project has provided opportunities for training and professional development and has contributed to the education and training of undergraduate and graduate students and early career scientists, all of whom are from traditionally under-represented groups in science. The project has also engaged in significant educational and public outreach activities at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History, where the activities and results of the project were disseminated to the general public through lectures, public days, interactions with K-12 students, blog posts, and museum-produced videos. Through the research activities of this project, we have also deepened collaborations between Chinese and American scientists.
